report_title: IBISWorld | Iron Ore Mining in the US Jul 2024
executive_summary: Iron ore miners are highly susceptible to changes in industrial production. This is why iron ore miners were significantly impacted by the pandemic, which caused steel production to dip and many mines to shut down temporarily. Steel prices skyrocketed amid supply chain constraints as the economy recovered, pushing the need for iron ore. After the pandemic, miners experienced constant swings as revenue went up and down amid price swings and volatility from downstream markets. Overall, revenue for iron ore miners has been swelling at a CAGR of 5.9% over the past five years and is set to reach $7.0 billion in 2024, where revenue is set to plummet by 8.8%. Looking ahead, iron ore miners will feel the effects of falling prices. Nonetheless, they will still exhibit a consistent revenue flow from downstream markets. The Bipartisan Infrastructure Law stipulates that all iron ore and steel used in projects must be US-made, which will help drive iron ore miners' output. The Inflation Reduction Act will provide tax credits to consumers purchasing EVs and renewable energy equipment (think wind turbines and solar panels), all of which require steel as an input, bolstering the need for iron ore. Overall, revenue is set to dip at a CAGR of 1.6% through 2029, reaching $6.4 billion.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Iron ore miners face considerable price-based volatility
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Iron ore miners have faced severe volatility amid downstream markets undergoing massive shakeups throughout the period. Weakened steel production before and during the pandemic pushed down revenue significantly. Mining and steel production ramped as the economy reopened, which spiked iron ore prices and profit. As supply chain woes eased in 2022 and interest rate hikes deterred investment, the price of iron ore, revenue and profit fell. Even so, revenue exhibited a slight uptick the following year despite slumping steel production. This growth stemmed from a restocking of steel and a bump in the consumption of intermediate steel products. This late period growth also stems from the recently passed Bipartisan Infrastructure Act, which requires projects to source domestic iron ore and steel.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Unfavorable trade conditions cause issues for miners
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: US iron ore exports have fallen as they have to compete with massive low-cost producers like Australia and Brazil. Import penetration from Brazilian mines is rising because their economies of scale enable them to charge less than US iron ore miners. Exports to China have been a bright spot as US exports to China began surging in 2021 and the country started ramping up steel production. Even so, it has not been enough to salvage growth. The appreciation of the US dollar has been a thorn in the side of iron ore producers as it makes domestic goods more expensive abroad, deterring buyers. It has also made imports less expensive, which slightly constrained domestic production.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Green initiatives gives way to external competition
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Iron ore miners have been experiencing competition from expanding green initiatives amid rising environmental concerns. Many downstream markets increasingly rely on recycled scrap metal, eliminating the necessity for mining. Recycled steel retains its quality even after being used over and over. Using recycled steel can reduce carbon emissions by minimizing mining and steel production. It also helps reduce waste and mitigate landfill issues. The uptick in recycled scrap metal can also be credited to the advantages of electric arc furnaces, which use this material for steel production. These furnaces are more energy efficient and create less emission, providing cost-saving and environmental benefits for steel producers. Some states offer tax incentives or grants for producers that recycle or use recycled material, encouraging markets to shift towards sustainable practices and contribute to environmental conservation efforts.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Falling steel prices cuts into revenue
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Iron ore and steel prices will normalize as supply chain woes entirely subside. This will cause revenue to take a massive hit as downstream producers pay less for materials. Typically, lower steel prices reduce profit, but fuel prices will also drop, bolstering miners' profit, albeit slightly. Even so, purchase and depreciation costs are set to remain elevated, as most equipment requires steel as inputs. The Federal Reserve has expressed its plans to reduce inflation and will consider lowering interest rates throughout the outlook period. As rates push down, this will lead to more investments in facilities and equipment as iron ore mines continue to bolster efficiency.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Recently passed legislation continue to support miners
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Bipartisan Infrastructure Act stated that all iron ore and steel used in projects must be US-made, providing a consistent revenue source for miners. The CHIPS and Science Act will also aid miners since steel is used to manufacture various electronic parts. Even so, sales will be constrained as many manufacturers switch to electric arc furnaces, bypassing the need for iron ore. The Inflation Reduction Act will also spur growth for iron ore and steel as government tax credits given to consumers purchasing EVs will stimulate growth from charging stations that need steel. Tax credits for solar producers and increased offshore wind capacity will bolster steel production and iron ore miners.

China will continue to be a boon to US iron ore exports as the country looks to ramp up steel production amid rapid urbanization. Trade tensions between China and Australia could keep exports to China afloat. Even so, this may dwindle if the two countries' relations improve. While the value of exports will dip amid lower steel prices, exports as a share of revenue are set to creep upward. This can be attributed to the depreciation of the US dollar, which makes domestic iron ore more affordable overseas. Imports will be pushed down as a depreciating dollar will make it more expensive for downstream markets to purchase foreign goods. The recent infrastructure bill will also reduce import penetration as new projects require domestic goods.

industry_definition: The Iron Ore Mining industry mines iron ore, which is the raw input used to manufacture steel. Iron ore is extracted from open pit and underground mines.

positive_impact_factors: Demand from iron and steel manufacturing

key_trends: The performance of downstream automotive and construction industries
Volatility in iron ore and steel prices

market_segmentation.segment_description: Steel mills are the primary consumers of iron ore, using it as a key raw material input.
Iron ore is used to produce steel products for construction projects.
Other minor uses include production of cast iron, pigments, abrasives and ballast.

products_and_services.product_description: Iron ore pellets are spherical balls of iron ore used in blast furnaces.
Iron ore fines are powdery iron ore particles used in sinter plants.
Other iron ore products include lump ore and iron ore concentrates.

tier_1_suppliers: Mining Support Services in the US
tier_1_buyers: Iron & Steel Mills in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The iron ore mining industry is heavily dependent on the demand for steel production. As steel production increases, so does the demand for iron ore.
Economic growth and activity levels drive demand for steel and iron ore. During economic expansions, demand rises, while recessions lead to reduced demand.

international_trade_points.trade_description: The United States is a net exporter of iron ore, with exports exceeding imports.
Major export destinations include Canada, Mexico, China and Japan.

business_locations.location_description: Minnesota is a boon to the Plains. Four of the five largest iron ore mines are in Minnesota, bolstering the number of iron ore miners in the region.
Iron deposits in Michigan attract miners to the Great Lakes. The region is also home to many automobile manufacturers, offering easy access to a critical market.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Iron ore mining operations are subject to stringent environmental regulations aimed at minimizing the impact on air, water, and land resources.
Mining companies must comply with strict health and safety regulations to protect workers from potential hazards associated with mining activities.

barriers_points.barrier_description: New entrants must acquire permits and leases and undergo a lengthy approval process.
New entrants require significant investment in large-scale earth-moving and processing equipment.
It's difficult for new entrants since the US Steel and Cleveland-Cliffs control most high-production mines.

basis_points.basis_title: Secure the latest and most efficient technologies and techniques
basis_points.basis_description: Embracing and implementing new technologies can help iron ore miners reduce costs and improve productivity.
Having a skilled and knowledgeable workforce is crucial for success.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs continue to expand as iron ore miners depend on fuel to run their machinery.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Depreciation costs remain stable amid price environment
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Depreciation costs continue to swell as expenditure on new equipment and facilities depends on the price of steel.
